Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Large: Collaborative Research:Programmable Inter-Domain Observation and Control

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Internet is an essential part of modern society, playing a vital role in a wide range of educational, commercial, military, and social activities. However, network operators today have a limited ability to observe and control the paths used to carry traffic across the Internet. For example, although it is often beneficial for several networks to cooperate-e.g., a content provider and cellular network jointly picking the best paths from content to customers-existing Internet routing protocols make it difficult to share information or collaborate to select routes. These limitations contribute to a host of problems, including decreased path stability, degraded performance, and service outages.

This project will develop a system called IN-CONTROL that aggregates information from participating networks and active measurements into an inter-domain network information base (iNIB). The iNIB presents operators with a unified interface for making observations about global forwarding paths and a rich control interface for issuing requests to steer traffic along preferred paths. To build the iNIB, the project is focusing on the following tasks: (i) developing provenance-based techniques to obtain reliable results from computations performed over potentially-untrustworthy data (ii) designing deployable mechanisms for observing and controlling Internet forwarding paths, and (iii) building a scalable implementation that incorporates optimizations to reduce resource demands for answering iNIB queries. The intellectual merit of this research lies in developing reliable abstractions for observing and controlling Internet forwarding paths and a scalable implementation that can be readily deployed on the current Internet.

The broader impacts include reducing the fragility of the Internet, and broadening the interdisciplinary community of researchers working on problems related to inter-domain networking. This project also provides research experiences for undergraduate students and members of under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of this project, we invented a number of technologies designed to make networks and networked systems more reliable, easier to manage, and more secure.

The first intellectual contribution of this project was the design of a high-performance implementation of the NetKAT policy language. NetKAT provides intuitive constructs for specifying rich network behaviors, but early implementations suffered from performance problems that made it impractical to use in real-world settings. We designed improved algorithms and data structures for compiling, verifying, and monitoring NetKAT programs. Other researchers have since used this system in their work, which is available online as open-source software (see http://frenetic-lang.org). We published several research papers based on this work, one of which won an award.

The second intellectual contribution of this project was the development of new approaches for updating the software running in network control planes and data planes. Software updates are necessary to release new features, fix problems, or address security vulnerabilities. However, updates are difficult to implement correctly in networks, because users expect networks to be "always on." We developed algorithms for updating controllers based on "state transfer" and for updating stateful data planes while ensuring programmer-specified consistency properties. We published several research papers based on this work.

The third intellectual contribution of this project was the development of new abstractions and tools for data plane programming. We developed an open-source compiler from P4 to reconfigurable hardware. We also designed and implemented a static type system that eliminates several faults commonly found in real-world P4 programs. We developed a networking stack that provides predictable performance to users. Finally, we designed compositional abstractions for P4 to enable a modular style of programming. We published several research papers based on this work, one of which won an award.

The fourth intellectual contribution of this project was the development of new domain-specific languages for managing persistent data and formalizing property ownership. We designed and implemented Transactional Forest, a language and system that provides transactional semantics for ad hoc data stored in file systems. We also developed Conveyances, a formal framework that models the semantics of property law in the Anglo-American tradition. We published several papers based on this work.

In addition to our research, we also engaged in outreach activities aimed at educating students as well as our academic colleagues.
1. The investigator contributed to the design of P4, an open-source language for data plane programming.
2. The investigator organized inter-disciplinary workshops on topics at the intersection of programming languages and networking. 
3. Project funds provided partial support for postdoctoral scholars, PhD students, and undergraduate students, all of whom received valuable training in an interdisciplinary area and have gone on to various careers in academia and industry.
